bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to William S. Thayer, September 26, 1930

div1.p: Laura Carter writes that she is thankful the work on her father's book is complete. She comments on her financial situation and her health.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to William S. Thayer, September 26, 1930
div1.opener:
Miscl Thayer
File.
Carbon
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
September 26, 1930.
Dear Doctor Thayer:
div1.p:
When last I had the privelege of seeing you, you asked me to
promise to write you frankly this fall just how things would be with me
when the work on Father's book was completed.

I am profoundly thankful to be able to tell you that the work is
really completed, save for a few minor details, Dr. Frost having devoted
the greater part of the past few months to the completion of the final edit-
ing. Indeed, I trust that by the time this letter reaches you, the MS,
maps, tracings etc. will all be on their way to New York. in advance
of “the October meeting of the Board.” Just when this occurs, I do not
know, but I judge that at that time everything left to be decided on about
the book will be finally settled.

Dr. Frost has done a beautiful piece of work, as was, of course,
to have been expected. In the truest sense of the word, then: “it is well”
with me, although by no means so well as if the work could have been completed
at the time of our original estimate. The many unavoidable delays will
always be a source of profound regret to me: a regret far more keen on ac-
count of disappointing the expectations of our friends of the Rockefeller
Foundation (who had made the work possible) than for its effect on my-
self. It has been, however, a solace during this time of anxiety and stress,
to realize that the MS of the book (as Father left it) was always available
to them for reference, even though the book “as Father wished it” was de-
layed.

As to myself, I should like to take back my promise to
you and end my letter here with the tidings I know will be so welcome to
you! Happy Pheidippides! The “anti-climax of the future,” presented no
problem to him, no solicitude to his friends! For myself, owing to cir-
cumstances beyond anyone's control, it seems inevitable that my future will
be somewhat in the nature of an anti-climax.

When Father decided to take up the work on the book (which he did
with my most whole-hearted assent!) he told me that he expected that its
completion (or the completion of so much of it as was possible to him)
would “about use up our joint working capacity.” This, however, seemed the
best use to which we could put our combined efforts and I shall always be
thankful for his decision. At first Father was unwilling to received re-
muneration for his work (lest he die before completing enough of it to be
of use). Later, through the delicacy and generosity of Dr. Rose and Dr.
Russell the matter of salary was settled on a basis which he felt he could
accept, and Father was able (prior to developing angina) to add materially
to his savings, which was a great comfort to him on my account. At this
time Father expected to leave me about $235.00 a month. Later, after he
developed angina, our living expenses in Washington were greatly increased.
This was chiefly on account of having to give up our rooms in the little
frame house on California St., and taking an apartment at the Westmoreland.
Here the elevator service made it possible for Father to get out of doors
and continue his work at the Library of Congress when necessary. This
did not often happen, as he had the privelege of using most of the Library b
books at home. There were times, however, when he felt it essential to his
work to go to the Library in person.

Father's last illness too was a time when we had to draw heavily
heavily
-2-
upon our resources, but, thanks to the forethought of the arrangement
made about his salary, this could be readily done. That it would have
been done in any event is true. Still, I shall always be grateful that, it re-
lieved him of material anxieties during that long and dreadful time.

After Father's death, when my health was considered sufficiently
improved for me to resume work on the preparation of Father's MS for
publication (for which privelege I shall always be grateful to Dr. Vincent)
it was again necessary (despite the generosity of the International Health
Board) for me to go into my capital on several occasions: Twice on account
of long illnesses (on sick leave without pay) and at other times on
account of matters (inherited responsibilities etc.) which I paid to have
handled by others, in order to keep all of my time free, in anticipation
of the early completion of the book. A bad bargain, as things turned out.
Still, Father had been brilliantly successful in “buying time” (from his
own capital) to press the yellow fever work in Peru, and I felt that I could
do no less if, by thus pushing aside all personal problems, I could keep
my time entirely free for the book.

Also, from January 1, 1930 to September 1, 1930 I have been going
regularly into my capital each month in order to keep my apartment at the
Westmoreland, with its office equipment in connection with the book, as
a “workshop” for Miss Brown and myself. This, in anticipation of the
“winding up” of details in connection with the final editing. This ex-
tra inroad into my capital has been necessary, in order to keep the apart-
ment, because, in the expectation that the book would go to press before
the end of 1929, there was no budget item for my salary, on a half pay
basis, for 1930. This was perfectly natural, as we all thought that the
book would go to press before the end of 1929 and I consider it a privelege
to have been able to continue my share of the work under any conditions.
However, on my return from a stay of several weeks in Baltimore this Au-
gust (during which time the book had reached an almost completed form) I
had a chance to give up my apartment and share one with Brown and her
Mother, without feeling that the change would interfere with what was left
of the work. It was a good deal of wrench, as I had hoped to “salvage”
my small bit of personal privacy out of much that I had come to realize
must go. Still, I am very thankful for the present arrangement, which
should enable me to stay on in Washington, with lessened financial anx-
iety, at least until the completion of the book, including the reading of
the galley and page proof, which I hope we will be allowed to go over, in
addition to the work of the proof readers of the publishers.

My cousin, Mr. H. Carter Redd, of Richmond, Virginia, who handles
the business affairs of the family, tells me that my income has been re-
duced to about $125.00 a month. Of this sum, about $20.00 a month will
have to be set aside for taxes (D. C. personal tax and my share of the taxes
of our (apparently unsaleable!) plantation in Virginia. If only my health
were better. I might (after the completion of the book) try to get some
work to supplement my income. I doubt, however, if I can ever do regular
routine work again. Certainly not unless I improve beyond my present ex-
pectations and those that Father held about me. I hope to be able to
get your opinion on this later, since you are infinitely better able to
judge about this than I. I regret to say that I am by no means so well
as when I saw you last, having lost 13 lbs. since the 5th. of last August,
at which time I weighed 114 lbs. When I left the Hopkins, after being un-
der your care, I weighed 126 lbs. However, I judge I am too old for “T. B.”
and too modern to “go into a decline!” Also, I am at present too thank-
ful about the completion of the book and too grateful to all those who
who
-3-
have helped to make it possible to dwell on personal “anti-climaxes,”
and have only written at you such length on the subject, because of my
promise to do so. That I have also done so in rather a rambling manner
is due to the fact that I have been feeling wretchedly for the past three
weeks, beginning with a digestive upset, one of the most unpleasant se-
quelae of my long years of chronic appendicitis. My eyes also have been
giving me considerable trouble, not in pain, but in the inability to see
things clearly. This, I trust can be corrected with stronger glasses
later on. During the past summer I could only do close reading with a
hand magnifying glass in addition to my spectacles. I must admit to some
apprehension about my eyes. Any serious trouble to them would be “the
ultimate calamity,” so far as I personally am concerned.

However, my personal concerns matter little to me in comparison
with the thought of the completion of the book and though
it comes too late for “Jubilates!” it is with a profoundly thankful “Nunc
dimittis!” that I face the future!

All good be with you always! The inspiration and help of
your friendship have been among the best things Life has given me, and I
have much for which to be grateful!

closer.seg:
P. S. I hope that you got my note, of last July, thanking you for “paving
the way” for me to write about the Marie Daughty Gorgas collection of
Peruvian silver. Mr. Forbes was away at the time, but I have recently
received a most kind letter from him, telling me that, although the col-
lection is not available for the Fogg Art Museum, he is trying to inter-
est other institutions or collectors in it. I need not tell you how much
Aileen Gorgas Wrightson and I appreciate this.
L. A. C.
